title: Australia’s queer community is under attack – are our laws letting it down?
description: Just days after a group performed the Nazi salute on the steps of Victoria’s state parliament at an anti-trans rights rally, a mob in Sydney attacked an LGBTQ+ protest group. Australia’s LGBTQ+ advocates say attacks on the country’s queer community are increasing – and claim that the protections offered by Australian law are lacking.Laura Murphy-Oates talks to non-binary performance artist and activist Kitty Obsidian and Guardian Australia journalist Cait Kelly about whether the country’s laws are failing to protect the queer community
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Cait Kelly and Kitty Obsidian; produced by Laura Brierley Newton, Camilla Hannan and Tegan Nicholls; the executive producer is  Miles Martignoni

title: Aston byelection: Dutton’s high-stakes battle for the suburban Melbourne seat
description: On Saturday, residents in the Melbourne electorate of Aston will vote to decide which candidate should replace the former Liberal cabinet minister Alan Tudge, who held the seat for 13 years. The byelection has been cast as Peter Dutton’s first major test as federal opposition leader in a state where the Liberal party recently lost its third election in a row.Chief political correspondent Paul Karp joins Jane Lee to discuss the battle for Aston, what it means for Peter Dutton and how people in the area are thinking about their vote.
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Paul Karp, Produced by Karishma Luthria, Jane Lee, Camilla Hannan and Daniel Semo who also did the sound design and mixing. The executive producer is Molly Glassey

title: Turning words into actions: the next steps for the Indigenous voice
description: We now know both the proposed question and changes to the constitution we would see if Australians vote yes to legislating the Indigenous voice to parliament. Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam talks to Jane Lee about what this wording means practically and how it has been received
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Lorena Allam. Produced by Karishma Luthria, Allison Chan, Daniel Semo and Miles Herbert. The Executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Australia’s kids are hooked on vapes – what are we doing about it?
description: The health minister has accused the vaping industry of making a ‘new generation of nicotine addicts’ amid rising reports of vaping addiction in teenagers and nicotine poisoning in toddlers. This comes as a vaping reform inquiry reveals an ‘overwhelming’ number of health experts and authorities support tighter border controls around nicotine vaping products.Medical editor Melissa Davey explores what Australia’s vaping crackdown – expected within the year – could look like, and the impact of vaping on kids
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Melissa Davey; produced by Karishma Luthria, Camilla Hannan and Daniel Semo. Executive producers  Miles Martignoni and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How Labor swept to power in NSW – and what’s next?
description: Chris Minns is now the premier of New South Wales. After 12 years in opposition, Labor will form a majority government. With an inexperienced frontbench, it faces a set of immediate challenges, while also having to tackle some of its key election promises – such as bringing in thousands of new nurses, teachers and paramedics amid a nationwide shortage.NSW state correspondent Michael McGowan explains how the night unfolded and what the state can expect under a Minns government
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Michael McGowan. Produced by Miles Herbert. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Does Labor’s climate policy meet this critical moment?
description: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has once again delivered the world a dire warning. This latest plea has cast fresh light on a long and fraught domestic debate. Is Labor’s key climate policy good enough to significantly curb emissions and will the Greens agree to a deal without a guaranteed ban on any new coal and gas projects?Gabrielle Jackson talks to the climate and environment editor, Adam Morton, and live news editor, Patrick Keneally, about whether Labor’s key climate policy will address the urgent call to action from the IPCC
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Adam Morton and Patrick Keneally. Produced by Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. Executive produced by Gabrielle Jackson

title: Why were neo-Nazis at an anti-trans rally in Melbourne?
description: Last Sunday a group of men dressed in black performed the Nazi salute on the steps of the Victorian parliament, amid a clash between protesters for and against transgender rights.Jane Lee speaks to Victorian state correspondent Benita Kolovos about what happened and Lydia Khalil, a senior research fellow at Deakin University and project director at the Lowy Institute, about the rise of far-right extremism in Victoria and why they’re targeting LGBTQ+ communities in Australia
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee. Produced by Miles Herbert, Allison Chan, Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How the Catholic church is blocking survivor compensation claims
description: Some Australian Catholic orders and dioceses are trying to stop survivors’ compensation claims for clergy abuse from going ahead in cases where the alleged perpetrator has died, arguing this prevents the church from receiving a fair trial. It’s a move designed to pressure survivors into accepting smaller amounts, their lawyers say, and is at the heart of an upcoming high court battle.Guardian Australia reporter Christopher Knaus speaks to Jane Lee about why the church appears to be returning to the aggressive approach it once took to save money and silence survivors
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Christopher Knaus. Produced by Laura Brierley Newton, Karishma Luthria and Allison Chan. Sound design and mixing by Joe Koning. Executive producer Miles Martignoni.

title: How AI fooled Centrelink, and could fool you
description: Thanks to artificial intelligence, faking someone’s voice is easier than ever – all you need is a few minutes of audio. An investigation by Guardian Australia has found that this technology is able to fool a voice identification system that’s used by the Australian government to secure the private information of millions of people.Data and interactives editor Nick Evershed explains how he discovered this security flaw and AI expert Toby Walsh explores how this technology could potentially make it easier than ever to steal someone’s identity or commit scams
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, Nick Evershed and Toby Walsh; produced by Laura Brierley Newton, Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The BBC’s spectacular own goal
description: A tweet by Gary Lineker led to his suspension by the BBC and set off a weekend of chaos in its schedules. Now with a truce agreed, Archie Bland reports on whether it can hold
contributors: Presented by Michael Safi with Archie Bland. Produced by Alex Atack, Tom Glasser and Rudi Zygadlo. Executive producer Phil Maynard

title: Aukus is here to stay, is it worth the risk? – with Lenore Taylor
description: After the landmark Aukus announcement, the former prime minister Paul Keating launched a blistering attack on the government – calling the trilateral agreement the ‘worst deal in history’. The response from China was even more pointed, accusing Australia of a cold war mentality and participating in an arms race. But despite all the sound and fury, are we any closer to understanding the geopolitical risks of this momentous commitment?Gabrielle Jackson talks to Guardian Australia’s editor-in-chief, Lenore Taylor, and head of news, Mike Ticher, about the need for scrutiny of the Aukus agreement
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Herbert, and Camilla Hannan. Executive producer Gabrielle Jackson

title: How did robodebt collect debts unlawfully for five years? | Full Story podcast
description: Hearings into the royal commission into robodebt have just wrapped up. Over many months, the commission heard from public servants, politicians and people affected by the scheme and a picture began to form of how the program continued for so long when so many concerns were raised.Social affairs and inequality editor Luke Henriques-Gomes speaks to Jane Lee about the key moments in the royal commission and why robodebt was allowed to go on for so long, despite repeated warnings of legal and ethical concerns
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Luke Henriques-Gomes; produced by Karishma Luthria, Allison Chan and Jane Lee; additional production by Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. Sound design and mixing by Camilla Hannan. The executive producer is Gabrielle Jackson.

title: Why is Australia spending up to $368bn on submarines?
description: On Tuesday new details of the Aukus agreement – described as the most significant multilateral defence partnership in generations – were unveiled. Australia’s acquisition of nuclear-powered submarines is meant to increase security and stability in the Indo-Pacific but the cost will be eye-watering and the project has drawn criticism from world leaders and former prime ministers.Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to Guardian Australia’s foreign affairs and defence correspondent, Daniel Hurst, about the risks and rewards of the Aukus agreement
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Daniel Hurst; produced by Allison Chan, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning; the executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Israel and the West Bank: a week of rage and rampage
description: Escalating violence by Israeli settlers in the occupied Palestinian territories is happening amid unprecedented anti-government protests. It’s no coincidence, reports Bethan McKernan
contributors: Presented by Michael Safi with Bethan McKernan; produced by Natalie Ktena and Solomon King; executive producer Phil Maynard

title: The teals, farmers and traditional owners fighting Santos
description: The rich farmlands of NSW’s Liverpool Plains have long been coveted by fossil fuel companies – BHP and Chinese state-owned Shenhua have both tried and walked away. Now locals are preparing to fight Australian gas giant Santos, which holds the licences for what lies beneath. The rural and regional editor, Gabrielle Chan, tells Jane Lee about the new generation of farmers taking on Santos, alongside traditional owners and teal independent MPs
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Gabrielle Chan. Produced by Allison Chan, Camilla Hannan, Miles Herbert, Laura Brierley Newton and Joe Koning, who also did the sound design and mixing, Theme music by Joe Koning. Executive producers Laura Murphy-Oates, Miles Martignoni

title: ‘Stop the boats’: Is the UK adopting Australia’s cruel mistakes? - with Lenore Taylor
description: This week the UK prime minister, Rishi Sunak, promised to ‘stop the boats’ and announced a new hardline stance on immigration. This familiar language shapes familiar policy. The inability to seek asylum, forcible boat turnbacks, offshore and indefinite detention led to an immeasurable human toll in Australia. But two decades later, after implementing a similar ‘solution’, the cruelty of the system remains.Gabrielle Jackson talks to Guardian Australia’s editor-in-chief, Lenore Taylor, and head of news, Mike Ticher, about the enduring inhumanity of Australia’s immigration regime and whether the UK will learn from our mistakes
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher . Produced by Miles Herbert , and  Camilla Hannan . Executive producer Gabrielle Jackson

title: The battle over Labor’s key climate policy
description: Negotiations over Labor’s major climate policy are in deadlock. With the government’s tight deadline to pass its bill to cut greenhouse gas emissions looming, what’s holding up this deal? And what’s at stake if the parties fail to reach a compromise?Guardian Australia’s climate and environment editor Adam Morton joins Jane Lee to discuss the details of Labor’s safeguard mechanism and who will be crucial to its success
contributors: Presented by Jane Lee with Adam Morton, Produced by Allison Chan , Karishma Luthria, and Jane Lee. Sound design, mixing and theme music by Joe Koning. Executive producers Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Ryan, Rugg and the right to work ‘reasonable hours’
description: Teal MP Monique Ryan is being taken to court by her former staffer Sally Rugg – a high-profile LGBTQ+ rights campaigner – over an alleged workplace law breach. Rugg’s lawyers say this case could change working conditions for all commonwealth employees and a larger pool of workers who claim they are being exploited.Laura Murphy-Oates speaks to political reporter Paul Karp about how this case ended up in court, what it could mean for workers across Australia and how it could change who gets to work in federal politics
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Paul Karp. Produced by Joe Koning,Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan. Executive produced by Molly Glassey

title: Crikey, Fox News and Rupert Murdoch’s shocking testimony
description: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch has admitted under oath that several Fox News hosts endorsed false claims that the 2020 election was stolen from Donald Trump and he did nothing to stop it. This testimony - revealed in a landmark defamation case in the United States - could affect another defamation suit brought by Lachlan Murdoch against independent news outlet Crikey.Laura Murphy-Oates talks to Guardian Australia’s media correspondent Amanda Meade and defamation law expert Dr Michael Douglas about the two lawsuits, what they could mean for the future of Fox news and press freedom in Australia
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Amanda Meade and Dr. Michael Douglas. Produced by Miles Herbert and Camilla Hannan . Executive produced by Molly Glassey

title: What’s in the air in East Palestine, Ohio?
description: When a train derailed in a small town in Ohio last month, it shed its toxic load, spewed smoke and set off a political firestorm that is still raging
contributors: Presented by Michael Safiwith Nina Lakhani; produced by Tom Glasser, Redzi Bernard and Solomon King; executive producer Phil Maynard
